section.title: From QED to Quantum Mechanics
section.p:

So of course Feynman, Schwinger and Tomonaga received the 1965 Nobel Prize in Physics for such a fantastic achievement.

The fields \psi and A^\mu are quantized. The first approximation is that we take \psi as a wavefunction, that is, it is a classical 4-component field. It can be shown that this corresponds to taking the tree diagrams in the perturbation theory.

The four potential A^\mu is given by: A^\mu=(A^0, {\bf A}) = (A^0, A^1, A^2, A^3) A_\mu=g_{\mu\nu}A^\nu=(A^0, -{\bf A}) = (A^0, -A^1, -A^2, -A^3) Note that A_0=A^0, but A_i = -A^i. The first component A^0 of the 4-potential is the electric potential and the potential V which is in the Schrödinger equation is given (as we show in a moment) by V=ecA_0. For the minimal coupling D_\mu = \partial_\mu + ie A_\mu we get: D_0 = \partial_0 + ie A_0 = \partial_0 + ie A^0 D_j = \partial_j + ie A_j = \partial_j - ie A^j We multiply the Dirac equation by \gamma^0 from left to get: 0=\gamma^0(ic\gamma^\mu D_\mu-mc^2)\psi= \gamma^0(ic\gamma^0(\partial_0+ieA_0)+ic\gamma^i (\partial_i+ieA_i)-mc^2)\psi= = (ic\partial_0+ic\gamma^0\gamma^i\partial_i-\gamma^0mc^2-ceA_0 -ce\gamma^0\gamma^iA_i)\psi
and we make the following substitutions (it's just a formalism, nothing more): \beta=\gamma^0, \alpha^i=\gamma^0\gamma^i, p_j=-i\partial_j, \partial_0={1\over c}{\partial\over\partial t} to get (i{\partial\over\partial t}-c\alpha^i p_i-\beta mc^2-ceA_0-ce\alpha^iA_i)\psi=0\,. or: i{\partial\psi\over\partial t}=(c\alpha^i(p_i+eA_i) +\beta mc^2+ceA_0)\psi\,. This can be written as: i{\partial\psi\over\partial t}=H\psi\,, where the Hamiltonian is given by (identifying V=ceA_0): H=c\alpha^i(p_i+eA_i)+\beta mc^2+V\,, or (note that A_i=-A^i): H=c{\boldsymbol\alpha}\cdot({\bf p}-e{\bf A})+\beta mc^2+V\,,
